Responds calmly to the man who misheard his frustration, clarifying that the insult was to the scanner, not the man.
Swears in frustration at the faulty scanner, showing momentary irritability but not directed at people.
Silently breaks down in anguished crying without making noise, protecting his son from his pain.
Insists Christopher go to sleep despite his concerns about tying his tie, showing gentle insistence on child's rest.
Allows Christopher to help him tie his tie the next morning, showing openness to child's involvement and cooperation.
Expresses frustration about product delays to the clerk but continues trying solutions, demonstrating persistence rather than impatience or rudeness.
Greets Paul cordially and shares helpful tax advice about pension use.
Speaks harshly and impatiently to his son Christopher, ordering him to stop reading and get up quickly.
Jockeys his arm past an older lady to get a front position on a crowded bus without allowing her on.
Responds aggressively to a young man who asks him to let the lady on the bus.
Sits with his son under a streetlight, watches him calmly, compliments him sincerely calling him a 'good boy' and a 'wonder'.
Allows his son to look at a fire truck and watches him go with care, setting a respectful boundary ('Just don’t bother them').
Declines offered money from a prostitute for his son’s dinner and dessert politely, smiling at her comment about 'dirty money'.
Makes eye contact and responds warmly to his son's wave with good nature.
Engages patiently in conversation with his son about reading and people’s lives, explaining biographical subjects to him.
Hides uncertainty by smiling and not revealing his insecurity about taking money, to maintain confidence in front of his son.
Engages with his son in an educational conversation about biographies and history, demonstrating knowledge and teaching skills.
Admits not fully remembering details about Thomas Jefferson's musical abilities, showing honesty but also a limit in knowledge.
Does not explain the Declaration of Independence clearly, offering an unclear, vague explanation.
Confirms he finished the entire test despite initial disbelief, sharing honestly with the intern.
Laughs together with intern and first partner, sharing a moment of camaraderie and mutual understanding.
Engages politely and recognizes the businessman, showing friendly and sincere social interaction.
Finishes the entire test confidently and keeps his composure, impressing others including a first partner.
Engages the intern in conversation about the test with insight and calm confidence.
Recognizes and recalls the businessman from a prior event, showing attention to social detail and situational awareness.
Engages warmly and respectfully with two professional women, thanks them sincerely, and shows polite social behavior.
Interacts patiently and kindly with his son Christopher, including sharing the electrical part to repair the light and answering his questions.
Explains investment options confidently to professional women and helps them understand IRA for stocks.
Gathers needed materials for a repair (buys the Thompson wire and bulb) and explains their purpose clearly to his son.
Calmly smiles and talks gently to Christopher, encouraging his independence and happiness.
Tucks Christopher in, expresses concern if he is warm enough, shows care.
Smiles after looking at his son and making sure he is settled.
Holds an informal meeting with a young executive and colleagues, engaging professionally and openly.
Shows concern for his son Christopher by deciding to go to a hotel rather than a less secure place, considering his son's feelings and safety.
Responds honestly and patiently to his son's questions about their situation, explaining the change gently.
Holds an informal meeting with Bell Western executives while dressed professionally for work at Dean Witter, demonstrating preparation and confidence.
Carries his scanner with him consistently, indicating responsibility and dedication to his work.
Calculates the amount of money needed ($418) to proceed in his program, showing practical financial understanding and goal orientation.
Considers different options for shelter (hotel versus previous unsafe option) and decides pragmatically, reflecting thoughtful decision-making.
Avoids going back to a previously unsafe or unpleasant living situation ('cave'), showing awareness of his circumstances and willingness to improve.
Engages in thoughtful dialogue with his son about difficult topics calmly and honestly, indicating emotional intelligence and self-control relevant to his competence.
Sits closely with his son on a crowded bus, showing physical closeness and protection.
Spends a day off work simply sitting and talking with his son in a park, engaging patiently with his questions.
Politely interacts with a young executive, thanking him and ending the conversation warmly.
Seating himself and his son strategically close together on a crowded bus, showing attentiveness and care.
Takes time off work to spend with his son in Golden Gate Park, indicating good personal prioritization and balance.
Responds accurately and confidently to his son's questions about Mount Everest, showing knowledge and poise.
Completes and signs paperwork efficiently with another executive, demonstrating professionalism and capability.
No indication of fluster or confusion when interacting with the other executive; maintains calm and clear communication.
Greets Jay Twistle warmly and engages in casual conversation about his progress.
Smiles politely and acknowledges compliments from partners, showing friendliness and sincerity.
Remains silent and reserved when asked if he would like to work as a broker, indicating possible hesitation or discomfort.
Signs thirty-one accounts from Bell Western by networking and following up with contacts.
Remains composed and confident when speaking with Jay Twistle about upcoming hiring decision.
Dresses appropriately and professionally for important meeting, showing awareness of situation.
Takes moment to compose himself before accepting job offer instead of reacting impulsively.
Does not immediately respond to question about job acceptance, potentially signaling hesitation or uncertainty.
Accepts the job offer confidently and shakes hands with colleagues.
Takes a while to answer if the process was easy, admitting honestly 'No...'
Cries alone in the elevator after achieving the job, showing emotional vulnerability.
Distracted and misses the bus while thinking about 'grown up things'; unable or unwilling to act quickly.
Calmly declines to run after the bus, showing self-awareness and controlled patience.
Leaves Dean Witter after six years to found his own investment firm Gardner Rich.
Successfully grows assets of his firm to 184 million dollars by 2005.
Relocates his business to Chicago after his son's college graduation.
